analytic.title: Sulfur diffusion in basaltic melts

biblStruct.note: Received May 27, 2004; accepted in revised form February 3, 2005

div.p: We measured the diffusion coefficients of sulfur in two different basaltic melts at reduced conditions (i.e., in the sulfide stability field), temperatures from 1225°C to 1450°C, pressures of 0.5 and 1 GPa, and water concentrations of 0 and 3.5 wt%. Although each melt is characterized by slightly different sulfur diffusion coefficients, the results can be combined to create a general equation for sulfur diffusion in anhydrous basalts:

where D is the diffusion coefficient in m 2 s -1 , the activation energy is in kJ mol -1 , R is the gas constant, and T is the temperature in K. Sulfur diffusion in basalts with 3.5 wt% water is a factor of three to seven higher than in anhydrous melts and can be described by: D ϭ 5.91 ϫ 10 Ϫ7 exp ͩ Ϫ130.8 Ϯ 82.6

At the conditions of this study the pressure does not measurably affect sulfur diffusion. Sulfur diffusion in dry basaltic melts is one order of magnitude higher than sulfur diffusion in dry andesitic and dacitic melts, whereas sulfur diffusion in hydrous basaltic and andesitic melts is within the same order of magnitude. When compared to the diffusivity of other volatile species in nominally dry basaltic melts, sulfur diffusion appears to be two times lower than CO 2 diffusion and two orders of magnitude lower than H 2 O diffusion.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Sulfur is an abundant volatile constituent in silicic and mafic magmas and a very important component of the volcanic plumes, typically being the third most abundant volatile after H 2 O and CO 2 (Symonds et al., 1994;Carn et al., 2003). Volcanic emissions of sulfur in the atmosphere have the potential to influence global climate (Robock, 2000;Blake, 2003) and to reduce stratospheric ozone (Solomon et al., 1996;Angell, 1997). Thus they have a strong effect on human and animal health (Grattan et al., 2003). Because sulfur in volcanic emissions can be measured relatively easily using remote sensing techniques, its analysis is a valuable tool for the forecasting of volcanic eruptions (Symonds et al., 1994;Malinconico, 1979;Chartier et al., 1988;McGee, 1992;Galle et al., 2003) and, combined with seismic monitoring, provides fundamental information useful for understanding magmatic systems (Fisher et al., 1994;Taddeucci et al., 2002). Moreover, it was demonstrated that historical basaltic lava eruptions released enough SO 2 into the atmosphere to have a climatic effect at a hemispheric scale (Thordarson et al., 2003), and recent eruptions at Etna and Stromboli volcanoes (south Italy) demonstrated that sulfur emission is significant even from smaller eruptions (Burton et al., 2003;Caltabiano et al., 2004;Salerno et al., 2004).

However, use of sulfur degassing to forecast volcanic erup-tions and to gain insights into degassing mechanisms, requires knowledge of sulfur solubility and diffusivity in silicate melts as a function of pressure, temperature, and melt composition. In the past decades many studies were performed to understand volatile behaviour in silicate melts (see McMillan, 1994, andBlank andBrooker, 1994, for a review of old studies; more recent studies: Behrens and Nowak, 1997;Nowak and Behrens, 1997;Zhang and Behrens, 2000;Brooker et al., 2001a, b;King and Holloway, 2002). Most of these studies were devoted to H 2 O and CO 2 in andesitic and rhyolitic compositions, with very few exceptions (Zhang and Stolper, 1991;Carroll and Blank, 1997;Pineau et al., 1998;Morizet et al., 2002;Freda et al., 2003). Interestingly, even though sulfur is clearly a key volatile species, few studies determined its solubility in natural magmas (Wallace and Carmichael, 1992;Carroll and Webster, 1994;Scaillet and Pichavant, 2003). Even fewer publications are available on sulfur diffusion, and these pertain mainly to silicic melts (Watson et al., 1993;Baker and Rutherford, 1996). Surprisingly, there are no comprehensive studies of sulfur diffusion in basaltic melts, even though mafic magmas are usually richer in sulfur than silicic ones (by a factor of two to four); the only studies on broadly similar compositions to ours are those of Watson et al. (1993), who studied sulfur diffusion in a lunar ultramafic composition, and Buchanan and Nolan (1979), who include a single data point for a basaltic melt.

To partially bridge this gap in our knowledge of magmatic system behavior, we performed diffusion couple experiments to measure the diffusion coefficients of sulfur in basaltic melts under reduced conditions. We are aware that large-scale convection might be a significant process affecting sulfur transport in magmas; however, a better knowledge of short-scale diffusion process is of particular importance to model the transport of sulfur in melts and its degassing. Understanding the diffusion of volatiles in silicate magmas provides the necessary tool for modelling processes such as bubble nucleation and growth. The physics of volcanic eruptions, indeed, is controlled by the dynamics of bubble growth (Sparks et al., 1994). In turn, bubble growth is mainly controlled by two processes: diffusion of volatiles from the melt into bubbles and the expansion of bubbles due to decompression (Sparks et al., 1994), thus it is apparent that the knowledge of volatile diffusion coefficients in silicate melts is a fundamental necessity to model magma vesiculation. Moreover, because sulfur is an important volatile component of magmas, we believe that studying its behavior, diffusion among others, can improve our knowledge of magmatic systems.

div.head: EXPERIMENTAL AND ANALYTICAL TECHNIQUES
div.p: We measured sulfur diffusion in basaltic melts using the diffusion couple technique. We used natural basalts erupted from Etna and Stromboli volcanoes (Sicily, Italy). The Etnean sample is an alkali basaltic lava flow erupted on July 18, 2001, from the 2550-m vent on the southern flank; and the Strombolian sample is a high-K calcalkaline basaltic pumice erupted from the summit crater during the paroxysm of April 5, 2003. We crushed and ground the samples, and to remove H 2 O and CO 2 present in the natural compositions we fused one set of aliquots to glasses in graphite crucibles at 1400°C. Initially both rock powders were fused at 1 GPa in a piston cylinder using a 1.91-cm NaCl-crushable alumina-Pyrex assembly; this procedure produced glasses of Etna and Stromboli basalts that contained negligible concentrations of H 2 O and CO 2 (based upon electron microprobe totals). This procedure reduced the S concentration in the Etna basalt to 160 ppm (Table 1), but the Stromboli glass still contained ϳ2000 ppm S. To remove the S from the Stromboli basalt we fused another aliquot in an open graphite capsule at 1 atm. At 1 atm the use of graphite capsules can result in the reduction of ferric iron to metal; to minimize this possibility we fused the Stromboli basalt for only 30 min at 1400°C. Comparison of this glass composition (Table 1) with the composition of the sulfur-and iron-enriched glass synthesized for the enriched half of the diffusion couple (discussed below) indicates that at most a small amount iron, ϳ0.5 wt% FeO, may have been lost during this procedure and subsequently removed from the products of this fusion by our standard technique of cleaning the crushed starting materials with a magnet. To create the S-rich starting materials we added enough ground pyrrhotite to the powdered Etnean and Strombolian glasses to create mixtures with a nominal concentration of 1500 ppm sulfur and fused these mixes in graphite capsules at 1400°C and 1 GPa for 2 hours in the piston cylinder to produce our sulfur-bearing glasses. As reported 1 we managed to add almost 1300 ppm of sulfur in the Etnean glass and almost 2300 ppm in the Strombolian one. To produce hydrated glass, we added 3 wt% water to aliquots of either the S-poor or the S-rich samples and fused them in graphite capsules inside welded Pt capsules at 1250°C and 1 GPa for 2 hours. In Table 1 we report the composition of the hydrated glasses: The water concentration in each glass, estimated by the difference from 100 technique (Devine et al., 1995), is 4 wt% in the Etnean glass (both S-poor and S-rich) and 3 wt% in the Strombolian glass (both S-poor and S-rich). We performed diffusion experiments in a 1.91-cm NaCl-crushable alumina-Pyrex assembly in a piston-cylinder apparatus at 1.0 and 0.5 GPa and temperatures between 1225°C and 1450°C for durations from 0 to 5400 s. Graphite capsules were used in all experiments to keep the oxygen fugacity ϳ3 log units below the fayalite-quartz-magnetite buffer. At this oxygen fugacity the dominant sulfur species in the melt is sulfide (Fincham and Richardson, 1954;Carroll and Rutherford, 1988), which has been previously shown to be the rate-determining species for sulfur transport (Baker and Rutherford, 1996). Most dry diffusion couple experiments were in graphite capsules inside pyrophyllite cups (Freda et al., 2003). We had technical problems using this assembly at 0.5 GPa and found it less problematic to use small graphite capsules in crushable alumina at this pressure. Hydrated diffusion couple experiments were performed in graphite capsules inside welded Pt capsules surrounded by a thin layer of pyrophyllite powder and placed in NaCl-crushable alumina-Pyrex assemblies (Freda et al., 2001). Each diffusion couple consisted of a cylinder of S-rich basalt and a cylinder of S-poor basalt. To create the diffusion couple we placed the powdered starting materials into the capsule and tamped them down with a polished rod; between the two halves of each diffusion couple we placed a "sprinkling" of Pt powder to mark the interface and investigate the possibility of convection during the experiments. Based upon the estimated melt viscosity of 20 Pa s and density of 2.5 ϫ 10 3 kg m -3 with the Pt density of 12 ϫ 10 3 kg m -3 and a grain diameter of ϳ1 m, we calculated from Stoke's law that the Pt grains gravitationally settled by at most a few micrometers during the longest-duration experiment. Owing to the very small diameter of the Pt grains and to the very small amount we used, we were not able to record any measurable reaction between the melt and the platinum powder.

Our pressure calibration for the NaCl-graphite in pyrophyllite cupcrushable alumina-Pyrex assemblies demonstrates that the nominal pressure is within 25 MPa of the actual pressure, whereas the NaClcrushable alumina-Pyrex assembly has a pressure 50 MPa above the nominal pressure as based upon our calibration; this 50 MPa pressure correction is included in all recorded pressures (Table 2). Experiments were heated to run temperature at a rate of 100°C/min and held within 5°C of the desired temperature during the experiment; at the end of each experiment we quenched the run, isobarically in case of hydrated experiments, at ϳ2000°C/min.

We mounted the capsules in epoxy and checked their geometry. All the capsules remained cylindrical (with the exception of sample 22E) and contain a few expansion cracks formed during quenching; these cracks were never greater than 20 m in width.

We analysed the sulfur concentration profiles by electron microprobe using 15 kV accelerating voltage, 20 nA current, and 10 m diameter beam. Major elements were counted for 20 s on the x-ray peaks and 10 s on each background, and sulfur was counted for 120 s on the peak and 60 s on the background. The standards used for the major elements were natural and synthetic glasses, and a pyrrhotite standard was used for sulfur. Minimum detection limits for sulfur were ϳ150 ppm, which is ϳ10 to ϳ50 ppm below the concentrations of our S-poor ends of the diffusion couples.

div.head: Sulfur diffusion in basaltic melts
div.p: In this equation, which describes diffusion at constant diffusivity between two semi-infinite media (Crank, 1975), C (x,t) is the concentration along the diffusion profile at distance x, t is the experimental time, C 1 is the concentration in the S-poor semi-infinite medium, C 2 is the concentration in the S-rich semi-infinite medium, and x 0 is the position of the interface along the diffusion profile. This equation was fit to the data using a nonlinear fitting routine that finds both the interface and the diffusion coefficient. The excellent fit of all experimental profiles to this equation demonstrates that over the compositional range investigated sulfur diffusion is not affected by its concentration.

Uncertainties in the measured diffusion coefficients (Table 2) arise from uncertainties in temperature, pressure, sulfur concentration, and the diffusion calculation technique. Our temperature uncertainty, Ϯ5°C, and pressure uncertainty, Ϯ20 MPa, are too small to have a significant effect on the measured diffusion coefficients. To test the analytical uncertainty we used a Monte Carlo technique which modified the sulfur concentration at each point along an analytical traverse by a random number between 0 and 1 multiplied by the estimated uncertainty, of 20 relative percent, at each point. This procedure was repeated 10 times to produce 10 surrogate data sets, and a diffusion coefficient was determined for each data set. This analysis indicated that analytical uncertainty results in a 12% uncertainty in the diffusion coefficient. Sensitivity tests of the fitting routine demonstrate that its precision is ϳ20 relative percent of the measured diffusion coefficient. Based upon these analyses of experimental, analytical, and computational uncertainty we estimate that our tabulated diffusion coefficients are accurate to within 20 relative percent.

To investigate if significant sulfur transport occurred during heating runs to experimental temperature, we performed a "zero time" experiment at 1400°C. This run produced a diffusion profile too short (ϳ160 m long) to require a correction to the other experiments for diffusion occurring during heating.

Because of the low viscosity of basaltic melts we were concerned that convection might have occurred in these experiments and affected our diffusion measurements. We used three different techniques to investigate the possibility of convection in our experiments. The first technique was the addition of the Pt powder at the interface of the diffusion couple. If convection occurred during the experiments we would see transport and dispersion of the powder in the diffusion couple, and this was not observed. The second technique was the measurement of replicate traverses on a few experiments. If convection occurred, the diffusion coefficients measured in the different traverses in one experiment might be significantly different. Duplicate traverses were made on three experiments: 8S, 9S, and 11S. In each case the measured diffusion coefficients were within uncertainty of each other, indicating that convection did not occur. The third technique was to repeat a run at the same temperature but for different durations. Although the measured diffusion coefficients are comparable (Table 2), they are not within our estimated uncertainty. However the measurements differ by only a factor of two and support our conclusion that convection did not occur in our experiments.

div.head: Effect of Temperature, Water Content, and Pressure on Sulfur Diffusion
div.p: Diffusion coefficients measured in this study at 1 GPa on anhydrous basaltic melts vary from 4.5 ϫ 10 -12 m 2 s -1 at 1250°C to 5.9 ϫ 10 -11 m 2 s -1 at 1450°C (Table 2). Sulfur diffusion in the two studied compositions (Table 1) show Arrhenian behaviour (Fig. 2) and can be described by the following equations:
Etna basalt: D ϭ 3.00 ϫ 10 Ϫ4 exp ͩ Ϫ223.6 Ϯ 37.6 RT ͪ , (2) Stromboli basalt: D ϭ 3.00 ϫ 10 Ϫ6 exp ͩ Ϫ176.2 Ϯ 47.9 RT ͪ ,
(3) where D is the diffusion coefficient in m 2 s -1 , the activation energy is in kJ mol -1 , R is the gas constant, and T is the temperature in Kelvin.

The diffusion coefficients measured on basaltic melts with 3.5 wt% water added vary from 1.2 ϫ 10 -11 m 2 s -1 at 1250°C to 4.5 ϫ 10 -11 m 2 s -1 at 1350°C (Table 2). Water concentrations were estimated in 6 experimental run products using the difference from 100 technique (Devine et al., 1995). The measurements in the three Etna experiments demonstrate that the water concentration along the diffusion profile averaged between ϳ3.5 and ϳ4 wt% (Fig. 3a), and the water concentrations in the three Stromboli experiments averaged between ϳ3 and ϳ3.5 wt% (Fig. 3b). These values are within analytical uncertainty, ϳ0.5 wt%, with those of the starting materials (Table 1) and demonstrate that no significant changes in water concentration occurred during the experiments. As shown in Fig. 2. Arrhenius diagram for sulfur diffusion in anhydrous and hydrous Etnean and Strombolian basaltic compositions. Sulfur diffusion for both Etnean and Strombolian compositions displays Arrhenian behaviour, based upon the Arrhenius fits to the measured diffusion coefficients at 1.0 GPa (solid and dashed lines, for anhydrous and hydrous melts, respectively). As expected, the addition of water to the melt significantly affects the sulfur diffusion in both compositions. In contrast, pressure has no significant effect on sulfur diffusivity in the pressure range investigated. Crystallization of the melts prevented us from performing experiments at temperatures lower than 1225°C. However, due to the Arrhenian behaviour of sulfur in the studied melts, we can extrapolate diffusivity to eruption temperatures. This extrapolation is only over a small temperature range, in which minor crystallization commonly occurs producing basaltic residual melts. As an example of this extrapolation, we measured the temperature of the lava flows with a bulk composition comparable to that used for the experiments which erupted at Stromboli during the last effusive period (December 2002-July 2003) to be 1090°C. Through use of Eqn. 3 we calculated a sulfur diffusivity in Strombolian basalt at this temperature of 5.3 ϫ 10 -13 m 2 s -1 .

To check for the effect of pressure on sulfur diffusion we performed additional experiments at 0.5 GPa (Table 2). As shown in Figure 2 there is no significant pressure effect on sulfur diffusivity in the pressure range investigated: All 0.5-GPa experiments yielded diffusion coefficients within the error of experiments at 1 GPa.

div.head: Comparison with Sulfur Diffusion in Other Melt Compositions
div.p: Although our results demonstrate that melt composition has an effect on sulfur diffusion, over the range of the two basaltic melts investigated we believe that this effect can be considered minor and we suggest that, until more information is available, the anhydrous data can be combined to create a generic equation for the prediction of sulfur diffusion in anhydrous basaltic melts:

Although not as accurate as the individual equations describing sulfur diffusion in the two different melts (Eqns. 2 and 3), this equation reproduces all of our anhydrous experimental results to within a factor of 2.

In the two hydrous compositions, the sulfur diffusivity differs even less than in anhydrous melts, even though the experimental water concentrations in the two melt compositions were different. The higher values of sulfur diffusion in the Etnean melts are consistent with the greater concentration of water in those experiments, but even under anhydrous conditions the diffusion of sulfur in Etna basalt is more rapid than in Stromboli. Thus, we cannot be certain whether the differences in sulfur diffusion between the hydrous melts are due to the small differences in water concentration or to differences in their anhydrous compositions. However, we know that once the water content in melts reaches a concentration of 3-4 wt% the diffusivities of elements are relatively insensitive to the exact water concentration (Watson, 1994), thus we can combine the two Arrhenius equations for sulfur diffusion in hydrous basaltic melts to predict sulfur diffusion in basaltic melts with water contents of ϳ3 to ϳ4 wt% water as follows: D ϭ 5.91 ϫ 10 Ϫ7 exp ͩ Ϫ130.8 Ϯ 82.6 RT ͪ . (7) Although we have no data on the effect of water concentration at lower or higher values than studied, we note that Watson (1994) reported a linear dependence of sulfur diffusion on water concentrations in andesitic melts at low oxygen fugacities; assuming a linear dependence for sulfur diffusion in our basaltic melts we find that at 1300°C it increases at a rate of 6 ϫ 10 -12 m 2 s -1 for every weight percent of added water, whereas sulfur diffusion in the andesitic melt reported by Watson (1994) only increases by 4 ϫ 10 -13 m 2 s -1 per wt% H 2 O. The linear dependence of sulfur diffusion on water concentration in these two melt compositions can be used for diffusion interpolations, but we advise caution in applying these results to other melt compositions.

With the generic equations we calculated from our measurements, we can estimate sulfur diffusion in basaltic melts and compare them to sulfur diffusion in melts of other compositions. Our data demonstrate that sulfur diffusion in basaltic melts is more rapid than in previously studied melts with higher silica concentrations (Fig. 4). Watson et al. (1993) measured sulfur diffusion in dacitic and andesitic compositions at 1 GPa under reducing conditions; Figure 4 shows that sulfur diffusion in dry basaltic melts is one order of magnitude higher than sulfur diffusion in dry andesitic and dacitic melts, though the activation energies of the three melts are very similar. The diffusivity of sulfur in a basaltic composition with 3.5 wt% water differs by a factor of 6 from sulfur diffusivity in an andesitic melt with 5.5 wt% water added, but the activation energies for sulfur diffusion in hydrous basaltic and andesitic melts are comparable. Baker and Rutherford (1996) measured sulfur diffusion in a rhyolitic melt under both reducing and oxidizing conditions at 1 atm and 200 MPa, to a temperature of 1100°C. They demonstrated that sulfur diffusion is not affected by oxygen fugacity until extremely high fugacities (well above the oxygen fugacity where the dominant sulfur species changes from S 2-to S 6ϩ ) and that, over the range of conditions they considered, sulfur diffusion is controlled by the reduced sulfur species (S 2-). Interestingly, diffusivity data obtained by Baker and Rutherford (1996) fit with the low temperature extrapolation of Watson et al.'s (1993) sulfur diffusion measurements in dacitic melt. If sulfur diffusion coefficients in dry basaltic melts are extrapolated to lower temperatures they will be approximately one order of magnitude higher than sulfur diffusion in a dry rhyolitic melt; importantly, the activation energies for sulfur diffusion in basaltic and rhyolitic melts are similar (Fig. 4). The only other comprehensive study performed on sulfur diffusion in anhydrous melts was by Winther et al. (1998). They carried out experiments on dry albite melt at 1 GPa, and temperatures between 1300°C and 1500°C. As shown in Figure 4, sulfur diffusion in albite is from 2 to 3 orders of magnitude lower than in basalt and the activation energy value is larger (two times) than in any other anhydrous melts. Importantly, Winther et al. (1998) found that reduced sulfur species (S 2-and S 3-) diffuse faster than oxidised species (SO 4 2-), confirming Baker and Rutherford's (1996) results. Baker and Rutherford (1996) demonstrated that the addition of 7 wt% water to the rhyolitic melts increases the sulfur diffusivity by 1.5 to 2 orders of magnitude (Fig. 4), qualitatively consistent with the effects of 3.5 wt% H 2 O in basaltic systems. Unfortunately they could not constrain the activation energy for sulfur diffusion in their hydrous rhyolitic melt, but it appears to be much lower than in basaltic melts.

div.head: Comparison of Sulfur Diffusion in Basalts with Diffusion of Other Volatiles
div.p: Before this study there were almost no data on sulfur diffusion in basaltic compositions, and data on the diffusion of other volatile species in basaltic compositions are few (Fig. 5). The only measurement of water diffusion in a basaltic melt is by Zhang and Stolper (1991), who performed experiments at 1 GPa and temperatures between 1300°C and 1500°C in melts containing a maximum dissolved water concentration of 0.43 wt%; this same study also obtained a single measurement of CO 2 diffusion at 1300°C. Watson et al. (1982) performed a study on CO 2 diffusion in a haplobasalt at 1.5 GPa and temperatures between 1350°C and 1500°C. We compared these previous data with those of this study (Fig. 5) and found that sulfur diffusion in a dry basaltic melt is lower by a factor of two than CO 2 diffusion in a similar composition. Sulfur diffusion in both hydrous and anhydrous melts is more than one order of magnitude lower than water diffusion in a basaltic melt with 0.2 wt% water dissolved. Note that the activation energies of water and sulfur diffusion in hydrous basaltic melts are comparable, as well as the activation energies of CO 2 and sulfur diffusion in anhydrous basalts. Therefore, in basaltic melts sulfur diffuses slower than other volatile species; this is consistent with the Fig. 4. Comparison between sulfur diffusion in basalts and in other melt compositions. div.head: Applications
div.p: Magma vesiculation is one of the most important processes affected by volatile diffusion (Sparks et al., 1994;Sparks, 2003). Therefore, quantitative knowledge of volatile diffusion coefficients in silicate melts is one of the necessary tools for modelling bubble growth. We demonstrated that in basaltic compositions various volatiles (i.e., H 2 O, CO 2 , and S) are characterized by different diffusion coefficients. In particular, sulfur diffusivity is lower than other volatile species. This could lead to volatile fractionation via diffusion during rapid magma degassing. This process can be efficient either during bubble growth in the magma or during fluid loss at the magma/wall rock interface (Watson et al., 1982). Owing to the lower sulfur diffusivity, a growing bubble will reach water and carbon dioxide equilibrium with the bulk melt faster than sulfur equilibrium. As a consequence of this behavior, the concentrations of exsolved water and carbon dioxide escaping from rapidly vesiculating magmas are more probably in equilibrium with the melt than the concentration of sulfur. Therefore, diffusion must be considered among the parameters that can affect the proportions of volatiles in volcanic gases (Wallace, 2001;Burton et al., 2003). We propose that some of the variability observed in the composition of gas emissions may be attributed to the finite time it takes for volatiles to diffuse through magma into bubbles. Of course, diffusivity data for other volatiles such as fluorine and chlorine (Baker et al., in press), volatile partitioning between melt and fluid phase (Scaillet and Pichavant, 2003, and references therein), and complex models of bubble growth are necessary to quantify the mass fraction of exsolved gas in magma before eruption. However, a discussion of these factors is beyond the scope of this paper.

Knowledge of volatile diffusion can also aid in the interpretation of melt inclusions in crystals, which are often used to estimate volatile contents in magmas (e.g., Massare et al., 2002). Melt inclusions form at various stages of crystal growth and record the volatile content of the magma trapped at the crystal/melt interface. If the diffusion coefficient of volatiles in the melt is slow compared to the crystal growth rate, the volatiles may be enriched at the crystal/melt interface (Watson et al., 1982); the amount of enrichment correlates positively with the rate of crystal growth. This enrichment of volatiles at the crystal/melt interface affects not only their own composition in the melt, but also the diffusion of other elements in the melt and the composition of the growing crystal. We need to estimate the volatile concentration at the crystal/melt interface of a growing crystal to accurately determine the volatile concentration in the bulk melt from that measured in the melt inclusion. Thus we need both volatile diffusion coefficients and crystal growth rates. Baker et al. (in press) demonstrated that a difference of ϳ4 orders of magnitude between diffusion coefficients and crystal growth rates is necessary to enrich the crystal/melt interface more than 10 relative percent above the bulk melt. In particular, considering a sulfur diffusion coefficient in anhydrous basaltic melts at 1300°C of 10 -12 m 2 s -1 , a crystal growth rate of 10 -8 m s -1 is required to produce sulfur concentrations at the crystal/melt interface that are not representative of the bulk melt. As a consequence, volatile content inferred from melt inclusions may be overestimated. This result suggests that the "excess sulfur" problem found for many explosive eruptions, by comparing sulfur emissions with data on sulfur dissolved in magmas as inferred from melt inclusions, may be even more important than previously supposed (Wallace, 2001).

Knowledge of the sulfur diffusion coefficients allows us to also quantify sulfur contamination due to diffusive processes. Sulfur contamination of magmas due to interaction with wall rocks is well recorded (e.g., Li et al., 2002) and appears to be efficient enough to precipitate sulfide ores. Nevertheless, according to the sulfur diffusivity measured in this study, the characteristic diffusion distance sulfur can cover at 1300°C is only 1.5 m in 10 4 years, probably too short to explain large amounts of sulfur contamination without invoking other transport processes in the magma chamber.

div.head: CONCLUSIONS
div.p: We measured the diffusion coefficients of sulfur in two different basaltic melts at reduced conditions in both anhydrous and hydrous (3.5 wt% water added) conditions. Although each melt is characterized by slightly different sulfur diffusion coefficients, the results can be combined to create two general Arrhenian equations, one for anhydrous and the other for hydrous melts. These equations can be used to calculate sulfur diffusion coefficients down to eruptive temperatures. At the conditions of this study sulfur diffusion is higher in hydrous basalts than in anhydrous ones (from a factor of three to seven) and is not measurably affected by pressure between 500 MPa and 1 GPa.

In dry basaltic melts, sulfur diffusion is more rapid than in dry andesitic and dacitic melts; whereas sulfur diffusion is within the same order of magnitude in hydrous basaltic and 5067 Sulfur diffusion in basaltic melts andesitic melts. Moreover, sulfur diffusion in dry basaltic melts is two times lower than CO 2 diffusion and two orders of magnitude lower than H 2 O diffusion in melts with a similar composition. The different behavior of volatile species in magmas can strongly affect their partitioning between melt and gas and thus can have important implications on magma degassing.
